info.name: Platform PublicAPI
info.description: This is a working copy of PAPI, since OpenAPI cannot see all endpoints some are added manually at the moment. More wll added over the course of onboarding developers and when endpoints come in and out of existence. Additional background knowledge will be needed to know what you need for each endpoint, some of course have dependencies in the database in terms of data, or require some order in operations. Feature documentation for the core functionality of the RunWhen Platform. To learn more go to https://docs.runwhen.com/public/

request.description:
For reasons that I can not understand, the allauth DefaultAccountAdapter doesn't
seem to call get_login_redirect_url in most cases.  It gets skipped,
and instead of it providing a 'sane' front end URL, I can only seem to provide
relative URLs.  So... this is here as a redirect.  It assumes the nxt_raw is a base64 encoded
absolute URL (any other encoding scheme gets yanked by Google oauth) and checks that it matches or endswith
a value in settings.LOGIN_ALLOWED_USER_PAGES_HOSTS.

Platform-created libraries (and their dependencies).  Only admins can POST, but
anybody (incl public) can GET.  Allows BasicAuthentication, e.g. w/ poetry:

poetry config repositories.runwhen https://backend-services.dev.project-468.com/pypi/platform
poetry publish -r runwhen --username tester --password ********

Note that pypi storage is shared across all environments, so uploading a lib on one env makes
it available for all.

Platform-created libraries (and their dependencies).  Only admins can POST, but
anybody (incl public) can GET.  Allows BasicAuthentication, e.g. w/ poetry:

poetry config repositories.runwhen https://backend-services.dev.project-468.com/pypi/platform
poetry publish -r runwhen --username tester --password ********

Note that pypi storage is shared across all environments, so uploading a lib on one env makes
it available for all.
API endpoint for CodeCollection objects

Gets file content in this repository.

If the path is a directory, this returns a json object with a key of 'files' that
has keys of filenames and values of their content, a key of 'snapshot' with various
statistics about this branch relative to the 'main' branch.  If a query param of commitCount
is included, it will return that number of prior commits in the snapshot.

If the path is a single file, this returns a key of 'file' with the file content.

This endpoint also supports 'format' query parameter, useful if a file format is natively yaml
but this should transform it to json.  This will parse any files ending in .yaml in to json, and send
the results either as a peer to the 'file' key with a key of 'asJson' in the single file case or as
a peer to the 'files' key with subkeys for each filename in the multi-file case.

While the argument is 'branch,' a tag or a hexsha are equally valid values for the 'branch' part of the URL.
API endpoint for CodeCollection objects
Get a series of statistics about which codebundles are being used most across the platform

A temporary get-in-place to unblock development of front end pages while CodeCollection and
CodeBundles finish migration to CoreResourceModels and the file processing is implemented in operators
rather than here.

Note this assumes that the codecollection has a path "codebundles" at the root.  Anything else will
result in no codebundles found.

Get as much info as we can about the current status re: syncing .yaml configuration files
in this repo to resources in production.
API endpoint for CodeCollection objects

request.description:
Endpoint to get a token for the currently logged in user.  For use with something like:

  import requests
  headers = {"Authorization": f"Bearer {access_token}"}
  requests.get("https://backend-services.kforster.dev.project-468.com/api/v3/workspaces", headers=headers)

Send a query param of "days" to specify the lifetime, defaults to being good for 1 day.

Endpoint to fetch all of the users who are 'networked' with this user,
i.e. they are in the same groups and/or have access to the same workspaces.
Used to fetch lists for autocomplete assuming that we do not have a problem
where this list will be too long any time soon.

Endpoint used for user search.  Search email, first name and last name fields,
and return a list of (rich) data structures for use by the front end.

Note this filters out service accounts.

Use a query param of "q" with the search term.  This will also return no results
if the search term is too short (currently 0, 1 or 2 chars) as the resultset could be
too big.  You can also use "q[]" as a search term with multiple terms, in which case the
results of the queries will be OR'd together.

For dev and early times only, if there is no q or q[] param, return all users for the front
end to cache.

TODO - this requires a lot more thought, and is prototype only.

Given a query param of q= or q[]=, search users primary emails and social
accounts secondary emails and return a list of user objects.

(Separated from general search for now as this is a heavily used call from the front end that
we may need to optimize, and may have different privacy considerations as the full email address
needs to be provided.  This is typically used when showing a list of git contributors and trying
to render that to user accounts.)

For front end convenience, returns an array of user objects under the key 'users' and an array
of email addresses (strings) under the key 'not_found' for any that did not match.

Endpoint for information about the currently logged in user.
For now, if user is not logged in, return http 400.

Endpoint for information about the currently logged in user.
For now, if user is not logged in, return http 400.

List of workspaces, sorted by most activities by the user

[
    { workspace_name: "test-workspace-1", count: 12 },
    { workspace_name: "test-slo-spread-ws3", count: 3 },
]

Activity count for the user -
Used to generate github-style heatmaps of user activity, this queries for all activities
where the user is the actor and returns a json structure like the one below:
[
    { date: "2021-01-01", count: 12 },
    { date: "2021-01-03", count: 5 },
    { date: "2021-01-05", count: 7 },
    { date: "2021-01-06", count: 22 },
]
Activity stream for the user - includes only the activities where they were the actor
Activity stream for the user - includes their activities *and* any workspaces they follow

request.description:
Returns a human readable string explaining the fields in the schema of this core resource
model (for convenience - same info is available in machine readable version at the paths
above).  See kubectl explain.

By default it will explain the spec subresource.  For other subresources, pass a query
param of the form sr=spec.codeBundle or sr=spec.codeBundle.repoUrl.  To show all fields,
equivalent of kubectl explain --recursive, pass a recursive=True query param.

Note content_type in response is text/plain by default.  If you give a query param
of 'format=html', it will return as preformatted html, format=json will return an object
with a key of 'explain' and a value of the string content.

Given the name of a resource ('Workspace', 'Slx', 'Sli', 'Slo', ...),
return all of the scehmas available for this resource.

TODO - over time, guarantee that the preferred schema is listed first
List the slack channels available from the token query param.  Token should start with xoxb-

Given a url to a workspace contents tar file, untar it and run it through the validiation
utility.  Return 200 if validation goes OK.

Takes a refresh type JSON web token and returns an access type JSON web
token if the refresh token is valid.

Takes a token and indicates if it is valid.  This view provides no
information about a token's fitness for a particular use.

Takes a set of user credentials and returns an access and refresh JSON web
token pair to prove the authentication of those credentials.
This is an endpoint for username/password login via the API, used for testing (and backdoor)

This is an endpoint that 'fakes' the Prometheus AlertManager endpoint and receives
events directly from Cortex.  I assume that this will get refactored out in to its
own microservice as this is not a public endpoint, but then it will call the hook/alert
endpoint that should be public with all of the labels it found.

This is an endpoint that 'fakes' the Prometheus AlertManager endpoint and receives
events directly from Cortex.  I assume that this will get refactored out in to its
own microservice as this is not a public endpoint, but then it will call the hook/alert
endpoint that should be public with all of the labels it found.

Run a robot test suite, streaming results back to the browser.

Note this *not* idempotent.  It is a 'get' only to make it browser-easy.
Shows the log.html from the most recent robot fun

request.description: Defaulted model endpoints

Used as a way to centralize user Create/Update logic with joins to other state, this call
is intended to be used when there is a change to a user account and other areas
(in the near term workspace permissions) need to be sync'd.  The assumption is that
the coremodels.User table is the upstream source of truth, and this reconciles other
state in the system to that.

(Future use may be to notify organization admins that a user has been added/deleted, update
CodeCollections and any downstream commercial applications, etc.)

A json body with a key of 'username' is required.  This should be able to be
called multiple times with no negative impact.

Returns a json body with debug info about state changes that came as a result
